column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=A Mississippi site in Kentucky where around 650 graves were looted over the course of two months in 1987 .
#Text=In the 1860s an amateur archaeologist named Sidney S Lyon mapped several mound groups in the Wabash/Ohio areas , including more than forty mounds at what is now called Slack Farm .
#Text=Slack Farm is a mound and village site which is located on the Ohio River near the mouth of the Wabash River , a few miles outside of Uniontown , Kentucky .
#Text=It dates to approximately 1400 to 1650 AD and is one of around eighty archaeological sites in the area that are associated with the Caborn-Welborn culture ( a Late Mississippian culture ) .
#Text=The site has seven discrete zones each with its own cemetery .
#Text=Burials at Slack Farm contain grave goods such as body adornments and pottery .
#Text=The site is named after the Slack family who had owned the property for a number of years .
#Text=The Slack family is thought to have discouraged illicit digging on their property , and the site was thought to be relatively safe in their hands .
#Text=Although most other Mississippian sites in the area had been hit by looters by the late 1980s , Slack Farm had remained largely intact .
#Text=Following the death of a member of the Slack family , however , the land became the property of another owner who leased it to two tenant farmers .

#Text=While some evidence indicates that the Slack Farm tenants attempted to keep looters off the property , in the autumn of 1987 a group of ten pot hunters from surrounding states paid the tenants of Slack Farm $ 10,000 for permission to loot the site while the fields were lying fallow .
#Text=At least 650 graves were opened by the looters over the course of two months , some with the help of heavy machinery .
#Text=Eventually concerned neighbours complained about what they saw as a large-scale looting operation which had exposed human burials .

#Text=Although the looting took place on on private land , any discovery of human remains in Kentucky had to be reported to state authorities ; allegations of disinterments prompted an investigation .
#Text=When Sergeant Miles Hart of the Kentucky State Police arrived at Slack Farm to respond to the complaint , he was prevented from entering the property by two of the ten looters .

#Text=Upon obtaining a search warrant , the looters stated that the area was an ancient campsite , that they had found no human remains , and that they were within their rights to dig on private property .

#Text=Yet scattered human remains were clearly visible scattered between around 450 looters holes and Hart returned with a cease and desist order , effectively stopping the looting in December of 1987 .

#Text=The looters were arrested and charged by a Union County grand jury with a crime applicable in the state of Kentucky at the time : that of ‘ desecrating venerated objects ’ , in this case human burials .
#Text=In 1987 ‘ desecrating venerated objects ’ was a misdemeanour in Kentucky and a conviction under that charge would only have resulted in a small fine .
#Text=Four of the ten men were residents of Illinois or Indiana and could not be extradited for a misdemeanour .
#Text=The misdemeanour charges were dismissed in March of 1990 for lack of prosecution .
#Text=As a result of the looting of Slack Farm , the state of Kentucky elevated grave desecration from a misdemeanour to a felony offence .

#Text=Slack Farm is often cited as an inspiration for the 1990 Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act ( NAGPRA ) , however NAGPRA only applies to Native American burials on federal land .
#Text=The Slack Farm burials were located on private property and would not have been protected by NAGPRA .
#Text=That said , Native American Groups have played a significant role in the activism following the looting of Slack Farm .
#Text=Several groups claimed the human remains from Slack Farm under the “ friends of the deceased ” provision of Kentucky state law , a claim that was recognised by the State Medical Examiner .
#Text=This has resulted in the reinterment of most of the human remains recovered from Slack Farm .
